discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: @chdoc @CohenCyril As written in the description of this PR, some deprecation notations for explicit application such as `@sorted_le_nth` do not let us write the first two implicit arguments `T` and `leT`. IIUC, this is a limitation of the deprecation mechanism of MathComp. I think we should rather turn them into notations without deprecation as in #640 for now. What do you think?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> @chdoc @CohenCyril As written in the description of this PR, some deprecation notations for explicit application such as `@sorted_le_nth` do not let us write the first two implicit arguments `T` and `leT`. IIUC, this is a limitation of the deprecation mechanism of MathComp. I think we should rather turn them into notations without deprecation as in #640 for now. What do you think?

How about setting an intermediate notation e.g. `sorted_leq_nth_subdef` with no maximal implicit?

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: @CohenCyril If we pass such `sorted_leq_nth_subdef` as the second argument of `deprecate`, the deprecation message says `use sorted_leq_nth_subdef instead`.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: OK, I found a solution. This should be fine.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
This one still does not behave the same as `sorted_leq_index` wrt to apply:
```coq
Goal forall (s : seq nat) (srt_s : sorted leq s), {in s &, forall x y, index x s <= index y s -> x <= y}.
move => s srt_s. 
Fail apply: leq_index.
apply: sorted_leq_index. 
```
This is literally the first example I tried.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: So we should remove the first two placeholders here as well.
